# History of gravitational theory

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

In [physics](/wiki/Physics "Physics"), [theories of
gravitation](/wiki/Theories_of_gravitation "Theories of gravitation")
postulate mechanisms of interaction governing the movements of bodies with
mass. There have been numerous theories of gravitation since ancient times.

## Contents

  * 1 Antiquity
    * 1.1 Greece
    * 1.2 India
  * 2 Modern era
    * 2.1 Newton's theory of gravitation
    * 2.2 Mechanical explanations of gravitation
    * 2.3 General relativity
    * 2.4 Gravity and quantum mechanics
  * 3 See also
  * 4 References

##
Antiquity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_gravitational_theory&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Antiquity")]

See also: [Aristotelian physics](/wiki/Aristotelian_physics "Aristotelian
physics")

###
Greece[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_gravitational_theory&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Greece")]

In the 4th century BC, the [Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece")
philosopher [Aristotle](/wiki/Aristotle "Aristotle") believed that there is no
[effect](/wiki/Causality "Causality") or [motion](/wiki/Motion_\(physics\)
"Motion \(physics\)") without a [cause](/wiki/Causality "Causality"). The
cause of the downward motion of heavy bodies, such as the element
[earth](/wiki/Earth_\(classical_element\) "Earth \(classical element\)"), was
related to their [nature](/wiki/Nature_\(philosophy\) "Nature
\(philosophy\)"), which caused them to move downward toward the center of the
universe, which was their natural place. Conversely, light bodies such as the
element [fire](/wiki/Fire_\(classical_element\) "Fire \(classical element\)"),
move by their nature upward toward the inner surface of the
[sphere](/wiki/Celestial_spheres "Celestial spheres") of the Moon. Thus in
Aristotle's system heavy bodies are not attracted to the Earth by an external
force of gravity, but tend toward the center of the universe because of an
inner _gravitas_ or heaviness.[1][2]

In Book VII of his _[De Architectura](/wiki/De_Architectura "De
Architectura")_ , the Roman engineer and architect [Vitruvius](/wiki/Vitruvius
"Vitruvius") contends that gravity is not dependent on a substance's "weight"
but rather on its "nature" (cf. [specific gravity](/wiki/Specific_gravity
"Specific gravity")).

> If the [quicksilver](/wiki/Mercury_\(element\) "Mercury \(element\)") is
> poured into a vessel, and a stone weighing one hundred pounds is laid upon
> it, the stone swims on the surface, and cannot depress the liquid, nor break
> through, nor separate it. If we remove the hundred pound weight, and put on
> a scruple of gold, it will not swim, but will sink to the bottom of its own
> accord. Hence, it is undeniable that the gravity of a substance depends not
> on the amount of its weight, but on its nature.[3]

###
India[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_gravitational_theory&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: India")]

[Aryabhata](/wiki/Aryabhata "Aryabhata") first identified the force to explain
why objects do not fall when the Earth rotates, and developed a
[geocentric](/wiki/Geocentric "Geocentric") solar system of
[gravitation](/wiki/Gravitation "Gravitation"), with an eccentric elliptical
model of the planets, where the planets spin on their axes and follow
elliptical orbits, the Sun and the Moon revolving around the Earth in
[epicycles](/wiki/Epicycles "Epicycles"). Indian astronomer and mathematician
[Brahmagupta](/wiki/Brahmagupta "Brahmagupta") described gravity as an
attractive force and used the term
"[gurutvākarṣaṇ](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E0%A4%97%E0%A5%81%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%81%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B5%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B7%E0%A4%A3
"wikt:गुरुत्वाकर्षण")" for gravity.[4][5][6]

[Al Hamdānī](/wiki/Ab%C5%AB_Muhammad_al-Hasan_al-Hamd%C4%81n%C4%AB "Abū
Muhammad al-Hasan al-Hamdānī") and [Al Biruni](/wiki/Al_Biruni "Al Biruni")
quote Brahmagupta saying

> "Disregarding this, we say that the earth on all its sides is the same; all
> people on the earth stand upright, and all heavy things fall down to the
> earth by a law of nature, for it is the nature of the earth to attract and
> to keep things, as it is the nature of water to flow, that of fire to burn,
> and that of the wind to set in motion. If a thing wants to go deeper down
> than the earth, let it try. The earth is the only _low_ thing, and seeds
> always return to it, in whatever direction you may throw them away, and
> never rise upwards from the earth."[7][8]

## Modern
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_gravitational_theory&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Modern era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|

During the 17th century, [Galileo](/wiki/Galileo_Galilei "Galileo Galilei")
found that, counter to Aristotle's teachings, all objects tend to accelerate
equally when falling.

The relation of the distance of objects in [free fall](/wiki/Free_fall "Free
fall") to the square of the time taken was confirmed by
[Grimaldi](/wiki/Francesco_Maria_Grimaldi "Francesco Maria Grimaldi") and
[Riccioli](/wiki/Giovanni_Battista_Riccioli "Giovanni Battista Riccioli")
between 1640 and 1650. They also made a calculation of the [gravitational
constant](/wiki/Gravitational_constant "Gravitational constant") by recording
the oscillations of a pendulum.[9]

In the late 17th century, as a result of [Robert Hooke](/wiki/Robert_Hooke
"Robert Hooke")'s suggestion that there is a gravitational force which depends
on the [inverse square](/wiki/Inverse-square_law "Inverse-square law") of the
[distance](/wiki/Distance "Distance"),[10] [Isaac Newton](/wiki/Isaac_Newton
"Isaac Newton") was able to [mathematically](/wiki/Mathematical_model
"Mathematical model") derive [Kepler's](/wiki/Johannes_Kepler#Scientific_work
"Johannes Kepler") three [kinematic](/wiki/Kinematics "Kinematics") [laws of
planetary motion](/wiki/Kepler%27s_laws_of_planetary_motion "Kepler's laws of
planetary motion"), including the [elliptical](/wiki/Ellipse "Ellipse")
[orbits](/wiki/Orbits "Orbits") for the six then known [planets](/wiki/Planet
"Planet") and the Moon:

> "I deduced that the forces which keep the planets in their orbs must be
> reciprocally as the squares of their distances from the centres about which
> they revolve, and thereby compared the force requisite to keep the moon in
> her orb with the force of gravity at the surface of the earth and found them
> to answer pretty nearly."
>
> — Isaac Newton, 1666

So Newton's original formula was:

     F o r c e o f g r a v i t y ∝ m a s s o f o b j e c t 1 × m a s s o f o b j e c t 2 d i s t a n c e f r o m c e n t e r s 2 {\displaystyle {\rm {Force\,of\,gravity}}\propto {\frac {\rm {mass\,of\,object\,1\,\times \,mass\,of\,object\,2}}{\rm {distance\,from\,centers^{2}}}}} ![{{\\rm {Force\\,of\\,gravity}}}\\propto {\\frac  {{\\rm {mass\\,of\\,object\\,1\\,\\times \\,mass\\,of\\,object\\,2}}}{{\\rm {distance\\,from\\,centers^{2}}}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0aab6501a8e9379b68a05b789c758f6126e0cab1)

where the symbol  ∝ {\displaystyle \propto } ![\\propto
](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0e3a55007ba2f092d6cafe6d33598e0608b81150)
means "is proportional to".

To make this into an equal-sided formula or equation, there needed to be a
multiplying factor or constant that would give the correct force of gravity no
matter the value of the masses or distance between them. This [gravitational
constant](/wiki/Gravitational_constant "Gravitational constant") was first
measured in 1797 by [Henry Cavendish](/wiki/Henry_Cavendish "Henry
Cavendish").

In 1907 [Albert Einstein](/wiki/Albert_Einstein "Albert Einstein"), in what
was described by him as "_the happiest thought of my life_ ", realized that an
observer who is falling from the roof of a house experiences no gravitational
field. In other words, gravitation was exactly equivalent to
[acceleration](/wiki/Acceleration "Acceleration"). Between 1911 and 1915 this
idea, initially stated as the [equivalence
principle](/wiki/Equivalence_principle "Equivalence principle"), was formally
developed into Einstein's theory of [general
relativity](/wiki/General_relativity "General relativity").

### Newton's theory of
gravitation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_gravitational_theory&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Newton's theory of gravitation")]

Main article: [Law of universal
gravitation](/wiki/Law_of_universal_gravitation "Law of universal
gravitation")

In 1687, English mathematician [Sir Isaac Newton](/wiki/Sir_Isaac_Newton "Sir
Isaac Newton") published
_[Principia](/wiki/Philosophi%C3%A6_Naturalis_Principia_Mathematica
"Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica")_ , which hypothesizes the
[inverse-square law](/wiki/Inverse-square_law "Inverse-square law") of
universal gravitation. In his own words, "I deduced that the forces which keep
the planets in their orbs must be reciprocally as the squares of their
distances from the centers about which they revolve; and thereby compared the
force requisite to keep the Moon in her orb with the force of gravity at the
surface of the Earth; and found them answer pretty nearly."

Newton's theory enjoyed its greatest success when it was used to predict the
existence of [Neptune](/wiki/Neptune "Neptune") based on motions of
[Uranus](/wiki/Uranus "Uranus") that could not be accounted by the actions of
the other planets. Calculations by [John Couch Adams](/wiki/John_Couch_Adams
"John Couch Adams") and [Urbain Le Verrier](/wiki/Urbain_Le_Verrier "Urbain Le
Verrier") both predicted the general position of the planet, and Le Verrier's
calculations are what led [Johann Gottfried
Galle](/wiki/Johann_Gottfried_Galle "Johann Gottfried Galle") to the discovery
of Neptune.

Years later, it was another discrepancy in a planet's orbit that showed
Newton's theory to be inaccurate. By the end of the 19th century, it was known
that the orbit of [Mercury](/wiki/Mercury_\(planet\) "Mercury \(planet\)")
could not be accounted for entirely under Newtonian gravity, and all searches
for another perturbing body (such as a planet orbiting the [Sun](/wiki/Sun
"Sun") even closer than Mercury) have been fruitless. This issue was resolved
in 1915 by [Albert Einstein](/wiki/Albert_Einstein "Albert Einstein")'s new
general theory of relativity, which accounted for the discrepancy in Mercury's
orbit.

[Paul Dirac](/wiki/Paul_Dirac "Paul Dirac") developed the hypothesis that
gravitation should have slowly and steadily decreased over the course of the
history of the universe.[11]

Although Newton's theory has been superseded, most modern non-relativistic
gravitational calculations still use it because it is much easier to work with
and is sufficiently accurate for most applications.

### Mechanical explanations of
gravitation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_gravitational_theory&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Mechanical explanations of gravitation")]

Main article: [Mechanical explanations of
gravitation](/wiki/Mechanical_explanations_of_gravitation "Mechanical
explanations of gravitation")

The mechanical theories or explanations of the gravitation are attempts to
explain the law of gravity by aid of basic mechanical processes, such as
pushes, and without the use of any [action at a
distance](/wiki/Action_at_a_distance_\(physics\) "Action at a distance
\(physics\)"). These theories were developed from the 16th until the 19th
century in connection with the [aether theories](/wiki/Aether_theories "Aether
theories").[12]

[René Descartes](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Descartes "René Descartes") (1644) and
[Christiaan Huygens](/wiki/Christiaan_Huygens "Christiaan Huygens") (1690)
used [vortices](/wiki/Vortices "Vortices") to explain gravitation. [Robert
Hooke](/wiki/Robert_Hooke "Robert Hooke") (1671) and [James
Challis](/wiki/James_Challis "James Challis") (1869) assumed, that every body
emits waves which lead to an attraction of other bodies. [Nicolas Fatio de
Duillier](/wiki/Nicolas_Fatio_de_Duillier "Nicolas Fatio de Duillier") (1690)
and [Georges-Louis Le Sage](/wiki/Georges-Louis_Le_Sage "Georges-Louis Le
Sage") (1748) proposed a [corpuscular
model](/wiki/Le_Sage%27s_theory_of_gravitation "Le Sage's theory of
gravitation"), using some sort of screening or shadowing mechanism. Later a
similar model was created by [Hendrik Lorentz](/wiki/Hendrik_Lorentz "Hendrik
Lorentz"), who used [electromagnetic
radiation](/wiki/Electromagnetic_radiation "Electromagnetic radiation")
instead of the corpuscles. [Isaac Newton](/wiki/Isaac_Newton "Isaac Newton")
(1675) and [Bernhard Riemann](/wiki/Bernhard_Riemann "Bernhard Riemann")
(1853) argued that aether streams carry all bodies to each other. Newton
(1717) and [Leonhard Euler](/wiki/Leonhard_Euler "Leonhard Euler") (1760)
proposed a model, in which the aether loses density near the masses, leading
to a net force directing to the bodies. [Lord Kelvin](/wiki/Lord_Kelvin "Lord
Kelvin") (1871) proposed that every body pulsates, which might be an
explanation of gravitation and the [electric charges](/wiki/Electric_charges
"Electric charges").

However, those models were overthrown because most of them lead to an
unacceptable amount of [drag](/wiki/Drag_\(physics\) "Drag \(physics\)"),
which is not observed. Other models are violating the [energy conservation
law](/wiki/Energy_conservation_law "Energy conservation law") and are
incompatible with modern [thermodynamics](/wiki/Thermodynamics
"Thermodynamics").[13]

### General
relativity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_gravitational_theory&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: General relativity")]

Main article: [Introduction to general
relativity](/wiki/Introduction_to_general_relativity "Introduction to general
relativity")

In **[general relativity](/wiki/General_relativity "General relativity")** ,
the effects of gravitation are ascribed to [spacetime](/wiki/Spacetime
"Spacetime") [curvature](/wiki/Curvature "Curvature") instead of to a force.
The starting point for general relativity is the [equivalence
principle](/wiki/Equivalence_principle "Equivalence principle"), which equates
free fall with inertial motion. The issue that this creates is that free-
falling objects can accelerate with respect to each other. In [Newtonian
physics](/wiki/Newtonian_physics "Newtonian physics"), no such acceleration
can occur unless at least one of the objects is being operated on by a force
(and therefore is not moving inertially).

To deal with this difficulty, Einstein proposed that spacetime is curved by
matter, and that free-falling objects are moving along locally straight paths
in curved spacetime. (This type of path is called a
[geodesic](/wiki/Geodesic_\(general_relativity\) "Geodesic \(general
relativity\)")). More specifically, Einstein and Hilbert discovered the [field
equations](/wiki/Field_equation "Field equation") of general relativity, which
relate the presence of matter and the curvature of spacetime and are named
after Einstein. The [Einstein field equations](/wiki/Einstein_field_equations
"Einstein field equations") are a set of 10
[simultaneous](/wiki/Simultaneous_equation "Simultaneous equation"), [non-
linear](/wiki/Nonlinearity "Nonlinearity"), [differential
equations](/wiki/Differential_equation "Differential equation"). The solutions
of the field equations are the components of the [metric
tensor](/wiki/Metric_tensor_\(general_relativity\) "Metric tensor \(general
relativity\)") of spacetime. A metric tensor describes the geometry of
spacetime. The geodesic paths for a spacetime are calculated from the metric
tensor.

Notable solutions of the Einstein field equations include:

  * The [Schwarzschild solution](/wiki/Schwarzschild_solution "Schwarzschild solution"), which describes spacetime surrounding a [spherically symmetric](/wiki/Spherical_symmetry "Spherical symmetry") non-[rotating](/wiki/Rotation "Rotation") uncharged massive object. For compact enough objects, this solution generated a [black hole](/wiki/Black_hole "Black hole") with a central [singularity](/wiki/Gravitational_singularity "Gravitational singularity"). For radial distances from the center which are much greater than the [Schwarzschild radius](/wiki/Schwarzschild_radius "Schwarzschild radius"), the accelerations predicted by the Schwarzschild solution are practically identical to those predicted by Newton's theory of gravity.
  * The [Reissner–Nordström solution](/wiki/Reissner%E2%80%93Nordstr%C3%B6m_black_hole "Reissner–Nordström black hole"), in which the central object has an electrical charge. For charges with a [geometrized](/wiki/Geometrized "Geometrized") length which are less than the geometrized length of the mass of the object, this solution produces black holes with an [event horizon](/wiki/Event_horizon "Event horizon") surrounding a [Cauchy horizon](/wiki/Cauchy_horizon "Cauchy horizon").
  * The [Kerr solution](/wiki/Kerr_solution "Kerr solution") for rotating massive objects. This solution also produces black holes with multiple horizons.
  * The [cosmological](/wiki/Physical_cosmology "Physical cosmology") [Robertson–Walker solution](/wiki/Robertson%E2%80%93Walker_coordinates "Robertson–Walker coordinates"), which predicts the expansion of the [universe](/wiki/Universe "Universe").

General relativity has enjoyed much success because of the way its predictions
of phenomena which are not called for by the older theory of gravity have been
regularly confirmed. For example:

  * General relativity accounts for the anomalous [perihelion](/wiki/Apsis "Apsis") [precession](/wiki/Precession "Precession") of the planet [Mercury](/wiki/Mercury_\(planet\) "Mercury \(planet\)").
  * The prediction that time runs slower at lower potentials has been confirmed by the [Pound–Rebka experiment](/wiki/Pound%E2%80%93Rebka_experiment "Pound–Rebka experiment"), the [Hafele–Keating experiment](/wiki/Hafele%E2%80%93Keating_experiment "Hafele–Keating experiment"), and the [GPS](/wiki/GPS "GPS").
  * The prediction of the deflection of light was first confirmed by [Arthur Eddington](/wiki/Arthur_Eddington "Arthur Eddington") in 1919, and has more recently been strongly confirmed through the use of a [quasar](/wiki/Quasar "Quasar") which passes behind the Sun as seen from the Earth. See also [gravitational lensing](/wiki/Gravitational_lensing "Gravitational lensing").
  * The [time delay of light](/wiki/Time_delay_of_light "Time delay of light") passing close to a massive object was first identified by [Irwin Shapiro](/wiki/Irwin_Shapiro "Irwin Shapiro") in 1964 in interplanetary spacecraft signals.
  * [Gravitational radiation](/wiki/Gravitational_radiation "Gravitational radiation") has been indirectly confirmed through studies of binary [pulsars](/wiki/Pulsar "Pulsar"). In 2016, the [LIGO](/wiki/LIGO "LIGO") experiments directly detected gravitational radiation from two colliding black holes, making this the first direct observation of both the gravitational radiation as well as black holes.
  * The expansion of the universe (predicted by the [Robertson–Walker metric](/wiki/Robertson%E2%80%93Walker_metric "Robertson–Walker metric")) was confirmed by [Edwin Hubble](/wiki/Edwin_Hubble "Edwin Hubble") in 1929.

### Gravity and quantum
mechanics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_gravitational_theory&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Gravity and quantum mechanics")]

Main articles: [Graviton](/wiki/Graviton "Graviton") and [Quantum
gravity](/wiki/Quantum_gravity "Quantum gravity")

Several decades after the discovery of general relativity it was realized that
it cannot be the complete theory of gravity because it is incompatible with
[quantum mechanics](/wiki/Quantum_mechanics "Quantum mechanics").[14] Later it
was understood that it is possible to describe gravity in the framework of
[quantum field theory](/wiki/Quantum_field_theory "Quantum field theory") like
the other [fundamental forces](/wiki/Fundamental_forces "Fundamental forces").
In this framework the attractive force of gravity arises due to exchange of
[virtual](/wiki/Virtual_particle "Virtual particle")
[gravitons](/wiki/Gravitons "Gravitons"), in the same way as the
electromagnetic force arises from exchange of virtual [photons](/wiki/Photons
"Photons").[15][16] This reproduces general relativity in the [classical
limit](/wiki/Classical_limit "Classical limit"), but only at the linearized
level and postulating that the conditions for the applicability of Ehrenfest
theorem holds, which is not always the case. Besides, this approach fails at
short distances of the order of the [Planck length](/wiki/Planck_length
"Planck length").[14]

It is notable that in general relativity, gravitational radiation, which under
the rules of quantum mechanics must be composed of gravitons, is created only
in situations where the curvature of spacetime is oscillating, such as is the
case with co-orbiting objects. The amount of gravitational radiation emitted
by the [solar system](/wiki/Solar_system "Solar system") is far too small to
measure.

However, gravitational radiation has been observed both indirectly, as an
energy loss over time in binary pulsar systems such as [PSR
1913+16](/wiki/PSR_1913%2B16 "PSR 1913+16"), and directly by the
[LIGO](/wiki/LIGO "LIGO") gravitational wave observatory, whose [first
detection](/wiki/First_observation_of_gravitational_waves "First observation
of gravitational waves") (named GW150914) occurred on 14 September 2015[17]
and matched theoretical predictions of signals due to the inward spiral and
merger of a pair of black holes. It is believed that [neutron
star](/wiki/Neutron_star "Neutron star") mergers (since detected in 2017)[18]
and [black hole](/wiki/Black_hole "Black hole") formation may also create
detectable amounts of gravitational radiation.
